carol s mericle cmc city clerkfinance director preface this a recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the city of wellington kansas source materials used in the preparation of the the 1996 ordinances subsequently adopted by the governing body the source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof the absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this the reader can locate any section of the 1996 any subsequent ordinance included herein the chapters of the been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage notes which tie related sections of the which refer to relevant state law have been included a table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the included at the back of this system the chapter and section numbering system used in this the same system used in many state and local government codes each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash the figure before the dash refers to the chapter number and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter thus the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 12 and the first section of chapter 6 is 61 under this system each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments for example if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 61 and 62 is desired to be added such new section would be numbered 615 new articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or in the case of articles may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject and in the case of divisions may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject the next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division new chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters page numbering system the page numbering system used in this a prefix system the letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume the number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion in the case of a chapter of the the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter in the case of an appendix to the the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix the following are typical parts of codes of ordinances which may or may not appear in this this time and their corresponding prefixes charter ordinances cht1 code cd code appendix cda1 code comparative tables cct1 state law reference table slt1 charter ordinances index chti1 code index cdi1 indexes the indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care each particular item has been placed under several headings some of which are couched in lay phraseology others in legal terminology and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees there are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested looseleaf supplements a special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication with this system the publication will be kept up to date subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited and the affected page or pages will be reprinted these new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages keeping this publication up to date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication as revised pages are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions it is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and in addition that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes acknowledgments this publication was under the direct supervision of alyce a whitson senior beth tattershall editor of the municipal tallahassee florida credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publishers staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the material municipal the city of wellington kansas 2009 ordinance no 4044 an ordinance adopting and enacting a new code for the city of wellington kansas  providing for the repeal of certain ordinances not included therein  providing a penalty for the violation thereof  providing for the manner of amending such code  and providing when such code and this ordinance shall become effective be it ordained by the governing body of the city of wellington kansas the the city of wellington kansas published by municipal consisting of chapters 1 each inclusive is adopted all ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before  and not included in the recognized and continued in force by reference therein are repealed the repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance unless another penalty is expressly provided every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the any ordinance rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof absent a specific or unique punishment prescribed shall be punished by a fine of not less than one dollar nor more than $100000 or imprisonment for not more than 180 days or both a fine and imprisonment each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall continue or occur shall constitute a separate offense the penalty provided by this section unless another penalty is expressly provided shall apply to the amendment of any whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance in addition to the penalty prescribed above the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances injunctive relief administrative adjudication and revocation of licenses or permits additions or amendments to the passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the city to make the same a part of the be deemed to be incorporated in the so that reference to the the additions and amendments ordinances adopted after  that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of part i  charter ordinances charter ordinance no 1  a charter ordinance exempting the city of wellington kansas from kansas statutes annotated and providing substitute and additional provisions on the same subject providing for the division of wards in the city into precincts for rearrangement of precincts for joinder of precincts for city elections for voting places and regarding poll books and repealing wellington code of revised ordinances 1956 be it ordained by the governing body of the city of wellington kansas the city of wellington kansas by the power invested in it by of the constitution of the state of kansas hereby elects to and exempts itself from and makes inapplicable to it of kansas statutes annotated which applies only to cities of the second class and to provide substitute and additional provisions as hereinafter provided in the city of wellington kansas the governing body may divide any ward into precincts and may rearrange the boundaries of the precincts when good reason in its judgment exists but so far as practicable the number of registered voters in each precinct shall be kept approximately equal when arranging and rearranging such precinct boundaries for each primary and general election as defined by statute there shall be one voting place in each precinct for each city primary city election and city special election all precincts in each ward shall be and are hereby joined and there shall be one voting place for such city elections in each ward at which all duly registered voters residing in the ward may vote in preparing poll books the city clerk shall prepare poll books for each precinct but for all city elections shall deliver to the election board of the precincts joined in each ward the poll books for the precincts joined in such ward for such city election rearrangement of precincts shall be by ordinance only the first precinct of the first ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying east of a line drawn north and south center of c street  the second precinct of the first ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying west of a line drawn north and south center of c street the first precinct of the second ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying north of a line drawn east and west center of harvey avenue the second precinct of the second ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying south of a line drawn east and west center of harvey avenue the first precinct of third ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying east of f street the second precinct of the third ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying west of f street the first precinct of the fourth ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying east of a line drawn north and south center of poplar street the second precinct of the fourth ward shall consist of all that part of the ward lying west of a line drawn north and south center of poplar street  this ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper this is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixtyone days after final publication wellington revised ordinances 195 and all other ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed passed by the governing body all of the members elect voting in favor thereof this 16th day of may 1966 charter ordinance no 2  a charter ordinance exempting the city of wellington kansas from ksa 14201 and providing substitute and additional provisions on the same subject relating to elective and appointive officers terms and compensation be it ordained by the governing body of the city of wellington kansas the city of wellington kansas by the power vested in it by of the constitution of the state of kansas hereby elects to make inapplicable to it and exempts itself from ksa 14201 which applies to said city but not uniformly to all cities and provided substitute and additional provisions on the same subject as hereinafter provided there shall be elected on the first tuesday in april of each oddnumbered year a mayor and councilmen as hereinafter provided the mayor shall appoint by and with the consent of the council a city treasurer police judge city marshal city clerk city attorney and may appoint an assistant marshal street commissioner and such policemen and other officers as they may deem necessary officers so appointed and confirmed shall hold their offices for a term of one 1 year and until their successors are appointed and qualified the council shall by ordinance specify their duties and compensation and by ordinance abolish any office created by them whenever they may deem it expedient the council may retain a licensed professional engineer for specifically devices duties and provide for reasonable compensation for the services rendered the mayor and councilmen shall hold their offices for a term of two 2 years and all other officers for a term of one 1 year  provided at the election in the organization of the city of wellington as provided by law there shall be elected two 2 councilmen from each ward one of whom shall serve for one year and one for two years and one 1 councilman shall be elected from each ward at each annual election thereafter this ordinance shall be published one each week for two consecutive weeks in the wellington daily news the official city newspaper this is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixtyone 61 days after final publication unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance as provided in subdivision c3 of the constitution of kansas in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by a majority of the electors voting thereon passed by the governing body not less than twothirds of the members elect voting in favor thereof the 3rd day of october 1966 charter ordinance no 3  a charter ordinance exempting the city of wellington kansas from sections 31 and 32 of chapter 274 of the 1968 session laws of kansas insofar as they pertain to the election and terms of councilmen and city treasurer and the appointment of city officers  providing substitute and additional provisions relating to the election and the terms of city councilmen be it ordained by the governing body of the city of wellington kansas the city of wellington kansas by the power vested in it by of the constitution of the state of kansas hereby elects to exempt itself from and make inapplicable to it of of the 1968 session laws of kansas insofar as they pertain to the election and terms of councilmen and city treasurer and the appointment of city officers and provide substitute and additional provisions as hereinafter set forth in this ordinance such statutory section is applicable to this city but is not applicable uniformly to all cities there is hereby created in each ward of said city two positions for councilman to be hereafter known as councilman position no 1 and councilman position no 2 there shall be elected on the first tuesday in april of each year one councilman in each ward of said city councilmen for position no 1 to be elected in the year 196 and in each oddnumbered year thereafter and councilmen for position no 2 to be elected in the year 197 and in each evennumbered year thereafter councilmen shall hold their offices for a term of two years and until their successors are elected and qualified charter of the city of wellington kansas is hereby repealed this ordinance shall be published once each week for two 2 consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper this is a charter ordinance and shall take effect sixtyone 61 days after final publication unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance as provided in subdivision c3 of the constitution of kansas in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by the majority of the electors voting thereon passed by the governing body not less than twothirds of the memberselect voting in favor thereof the 12th day of december 1968 charter ordinance no 4  a charter ordinance exempting the city of wellington kansas from sections 1410a02 and 1410a05 of the kansas statutes annotated and sections 8 and 10 of house bills 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 kansas legislature and providing substitute and additional provisions on the same subject relating to fire and police retirement systems the creation and maintenance of separate funds for each department tax levies designation of funds investment and their exemption from the limitations provided for in the aforesaid house bills and from the term operating expenses as used in said house bills be it ordained by the governing body of the city of wellington kansas the city of wellington kansas by the power invested in it by of the constitution of the state of kansas hereby elects to make inapplicable to it and exempts itself from a02 and 1410a05 of the kansas statutes annotated and from of house bills 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 kansas legislature which apply to said city but not uniformly to all cities and provides substitute and additional provisions on the same subject as hereinafter provided the city of wellington kansas may establish and maintain a separate pension fund for each the police department and the fire department of said city which shall be set aside and used exclusively for the payment of pensions and disability benefits as authorized herein for the purpose of creating and maintaining such pension funds the governing body of said city is hereby authorized and shall 1 accept gifts grants bequests gratuities or any other money and credit the same to the pension fund designated by the donor  2 levy an assessment against each officer and member of each department equal to three percent of his monthly salary or compensation the same to be deducted from the regular payroll and to be transferred into said pension fund  3 place into said funds the proceeds of all lost or stolen securities money or personal property which shall remain unclaimed in possession of any department of the city for six months together with the proceeds of all unclaimed or confiscated property of any nature which shall have been in custody of the police department for a period of six months and the city is hereby authorized to sell at public auction such property and place the proceeds therefrom into said pension funds in equal shares  4 transfer into said pension funds the unencumbered balance including investments in any existing pension fund or funds provided that if there is more than one pension fund existing in said city then each of said existing funds except the firemens and policemens relief funds shall be transferred into the new pension fund of a like classification  5 carry forward the balance in said funds at the close of each budget year as revenue for the next ensuing year  6 transfer into said fund any proceeds from any municipallyowned utility at the discretion of the governing body of said city  7 levy annually at the time for the levying of taxes for city purposes and in addition to other taxes authorized or limited a tax upon all of the taxable tangible property in said city not to exceed one and onehalf mill for each fund to maintain the said pension funds at a level to continue maintain and pay all pension and disability requirements actual or anticipated for the ensuing year and to maintain a reserve in said pension funds as is hereinafter provided the amount of money derived from taxes herein levied and all money received from assessments dues donations for the benefit of such funds shall constitute funds to be known and designated respectively as the policemens pension fund and the firemens pension fund which funds shall be devoted exclusively to and for the purposes hereinafter enumerated all moneys derived from the taxes so levied and money received from other sources as above enumerated shall be paid into the policemens pension fund or the firemens pension fund as the case may be and shall be cumulative until a reserve fund in an amount to be determined by the governing body of the city of wellington kansas shall be built up for each fund the amount of each reserve fund shall be determined by the governing body of the city of wellington kansas and when each reserve fund as so determined shall reach its maximum further tax levies shall be made only for the purpose of maintaining each fund at said level all moneys accumulated under the provisions of this act shall be deposited by the treasurer in the same manner as other city funds  provided however the board of trustees may at their option invest any of said reserve funds in direct obligation bonds of the united states of america maturing or redeemable at par and accrued interest within three years from date of purchase or in bonds of any municipality in the state of kansas the total bonded indebtedness of which is less than fifteen percent of the total assessed tangible valuation of such municipality which bonds shall mature within five years from the date of purchase the provisions of house bills nos 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 kansas legislature shall not apply to or limit the levy of taxes for the payment of a principal and interest upon bonds and temporary notes  b nofund warrants issued prior to the effective date of house bills nos 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 kansas legislature  c nofund warrants issued after the effective date of house bills nos 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 kansas legislature when authorized by the state board of tax appeals subject to the conditions and requirements of ksa 792938 792939 792941 and 792951 and where said board in addition specifically finds that an extreme emergency exists  d judgments rendered against the city of wellington  e rent due under any lease with a public building commission authorized by ksa 1969 supp 121757 to 121768 inclusive and acts amendatory thereof which rent is for a facility specified in a resolution adopted prior to the effective date of house bills nos 1825 and 2051 of the 1970 kansas legislature pursuant to ksa 1969 supp 121767 and is pledged to retire bonds issued under the authority of such act  or f special assessments and as used herein and substitute and additional provisions on the same subject relating to the cutting or destruction of weeds by said city and the assessment of costs therefor and repealing of the code of the city of wellington kansas 1969 be it ordained by the governing body of the city of wellington kansas the city of wellington kansas by the power invested in it by of the constitution of the state of kansas hereby elects to make inapplicable to it and exempts itself from ksa 121642 which applies to said city but not uniformly to all cities and provides substitute and additional provisions on the same subject as hereinafter provided where weeds are not kept cut to a height of sixteen 16 inches from the ground or are not destroyed and where the occupant owner or agent of lots or pieces of land within said city shall refuse after five 5 days written notice by the city clerk or in cases where the owner is unknown or is a nonresident of said city and there is no resident agent ten 10 days after notice has been published in the official city paper by the city clerk to cut or destroy such weeds the street department of said city shall cut or destroy such weeds as aforesaid and shall keep an account of the cost of the same and report the same to the city clerk  and the cost of the cutting or destruction of said weeds shall be assessed and charged against the lot or parcel of ground on which such weeds were located  and the city clerk shall at the time of certifying other city taxes to the county clerk certify the aforesaid costs and the county clerk shall extend the same on the tax 1972 charter ordinance no 7  a charter ordinance of the city of wellington kansas providing that sections 1410a01 through and including 1410a15 of the kansas statutes annotated shall not apply to said city exempting said city therefrom and providing substitute provisions therefore establishing a retirement system for police and fire personnel  providing for the financing of such system and prescribing the authority for the investment of reserves and the management and administration of such system  providing for the transfer of the accounts reserves and fund balances of existing police or fire pension funds heretofore accumulated under authority of the laws of the state of kansas  and repealing sections 9301 to 9312 inclusive and 16301 to 16312 inclusive of the code of the city of wellington kansas 1969 be it ordained by the governing body of the city of wellington kansas statutory authority the city of wellington kansas a city of the second class by the power vested in it by of the constitution of the state of kansas hereby elects to and exempts itself from and makes inapplicable to it a01 including a15 of the kansas statutes annotated name and effective date the policemens and firemens retirement system of wellington kansas hereinafter referred to as the system is hereby established for the purpose of providing disability annuities retirement annuities survivors annuities and death benefits for policemen and firemen of the city of wellington kansas and their dependents pursuant to the provisions of this effective date of the system shall be  but will not include any policeman or fireman employed after  definitions the following words and phrases used in this unless a different meaning is plainly required by the context shall have the following meanings a city shall mean the city of wellington kansas b board shall mean the board of trustees of the policemens and firemens retirement system c policeman or fireman shall mean in the case of a policeman any employee of the police department of the city holding the rank of patrolman including commissioned officers  and in the case of fireman any employee of the fire department of the city holding the rank of fireman including probationary fireman of higher rank including commissioned officers the term policeman or fireman shall not include 1 any person privately employed as a policeman or fireman 2 any person temporarily employed as a policeman or fireman for an emergency or 3 any civilian employee in the police or fire departments or 4 any person employed in either the police department or the fire department after  d member shall mean any policeman or fireman of the city included in the membership of the system and receiving compensation e service shall mean service rendered to the city as a policeman or fireman f prior service shall mean service rendered by a member prior to the effective date of this g membership service shall mean service rendered by member on or after the effective date of this h credited service shall mean the sum of prior service and membership service for which a member has received credit under the provisions of this i disability shall mean total inability to perform permanently the duties of the position held by the member at date of disability due to a physical or mental incapacity resulting from external force or violence or disease j serviceconnected disability shall mean any physical or mental incapacity resulting from external forces violence or disease occasioned by an act of duty as a policeman or fireman imposed by the ordinances or rules and regulations of the city or any other disability which may be directly attributable to an act of duty k nonserviceconnected disability shall mean all disabilities other than serviceconnected disabilities except disabilities incurred in private employment or in the national guard or in military service of united states or any of its allies l act of duty shall mean an act performed by a member within the scope of occupational duties during the course of his employment for the purpose of protecting life or property including any act of heroism as a member m withdrawal from service shall mean complete severance of employment of any member as an employee of the police and or fire departments of the city by resignation discharge or dismissal n actuarial tables shall mean such tables of mortality and rates of interest as may be adopted by the board upon recommendation of the actuary employed by the board provided however that for the first five years of operation the actuarial table to be used shall be that known as the combined annuity mortality table and regular interest o regular interest shall mean interest at 312% per annum compounded annually for the first five years of operation and thereafter such rate as may be prescribed by the board based upon the experience of the system p minor child or minor children eligible for consideration under the provisions of the ordinance shall mean children of the blood and legally adopted children q widow shall mean that person who survives the decedent that was his wife at the time of disability or retirement r wife shall mean that person who is the members wife other than at commonlaw at the time of the members death or retirement s vested rights shall mean a right that is absolute without contingency at a specified time membership membership of the system shall include in addition to those persons defined as members in d the following a any person who was a policeman or fireman on the effective date of this b any policeman or fireman who was temporarily absent on the effective date of this to sickness or disability or who was on approved leave for any cause provided such leave shall not be extended for more than one year continuously except for military service creditable service a credit as prior service shall be granted to any person who was a member of the system on the effective date of this the same periods of time prior to said effective date for which pension credit was granted under any police pension fund or firemans pension fund maintained by the city by whatever name called in which the member was a participant and for membership service after the effective date of this which the member makes contributions b credit for military service shall be granted in the same manner as if service was rendered the city uninterruptedly to any member entering the service of the army navy air force marines or coast guard of the united states by enlistment or induction during the time of war or other national emergency recognized by the board who reenters the employ of the city within 90 days from the date of termination of his armed service after discharge so long as said discharge is not dishonorable c in the computation of prior service or membership service 15 days of service or more during any month shall constitute a month of service and 12 months of service shall constitute a year of service in no case except for military service shall credit be allowed for any period of absence without salary nor shall less than 15 days of service during any month be considered for the computation of service nor shall more than one year of service be credited for service rendered in any one calendar year permanent serviceconnected disability benefits a any member who shall while engaged in the performance of his duties be permanently injured or disabled and upon examination by a physician or physicians appointed by the board be found to be physically or mentally disabled as a result of such permanent disability or injury so as to render him unfit for the performance of service as a policeman or fireman shall be entitled to be retired and the board of trustees shall thereupon order his retirement and upon his being so retired he shall be paid each month a sum equal to 50% of his average monthly compensation computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately preceding such retirement after five years of continuous credited service heart and lung disease shall be presumed to be a service connected disability b the board of trustees may when they deem it advisable call back for reexamination by a physician any member retired by reasons of permanent disability under the provisions of this if said examination discloses that said member is then able to perform his duties or any other duties to which he may be assigned in said department without reduction in salary he may be returned to service if said member fails or refuses for 10 days after call back for reexamination as aforesaid to submit to such reexamination or if said member after reexamination upon request of the board fails or refuses to return to duty then and in either event all payments from said system shall cease in the event such member returns to duty the time lost by reason of such injury or disability shall be included in his membership service for retirement purposes c any such annuity shall begin to accrue from the date of disability of the member provided that any and all payments received by the member during disability under the workmens compensation laws of the state of kansas or under other ordinances of the city or from any public funds of whatsoever nature except federal social security shall be applied to reduce the amounts accruing on the annuity nonservice connected disability a any member having at least five 5 years of credited service who becomes totally and permanently disabled due to any cause other than service connected disability except disabilities incurred in private employment or in the national guard or in the military service of the united states or any of its allies while an employee of the city shall be entitled to a nonservice connected disability annuity such annuity shall be equal to 228% of the members salary for the 12 months immediately preceding such disability multiplied by the number of years of credited service of the member  for credited service in excess of 22 years 11% per year of credited service above 22 years shall be added to said annuity provided however that no member shall receive under this a more than 66% of his final average monthly salary computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately preceding such disability such annuity shall be paid in 12 monthly payments each year b the board of trustees may when they deem it advisable call back for reexamination by a physician any member retired by reason of nonservice connected disability and all provisions contained in b of this to service connected disabilities shall apply to nonservice connected disabilities except however that in the event such member returns to duty the time lost by reason of such nonservice connected disability shall not be included in his membership service for retirement purposes c the annuity herein provided for nonservice connected disability shall be reduced by all sums of money received by the member under the workmens compensation laws of the state of kansas or under other ordinances of the city or from any public funds of whatsoever nature except federal social security d nonservice connected disability shall be considered total and permanent if it results in some impairment of mind or body due to mental or physical incapacity resulting from external force or violence or disease that substantially precludes a member from performing with reasonable regularity the substantial and material parts of any gainful work or occupation that he would be competent to perform were it not for the fact that the impairment is founded upon conditions which render it reasonably certain that it will continue indefinitely e a nonservice connected disability annuity shall begin to accrue upon the commencement of the disability provided that if the member is receiving salary or compensation the annuity shall begin to accrue from the date the salary or compensation has ceased if written application shall not have been filed with the board prior to the expiration of ninety days from the date of disability the annuity shall begin to accrue from the date application therefore has been filed but in no event prior to the time when payments to the member on account of salary or compensation have ceased f notwithstanding the provisions contained in c above pertaining to nonservice connected disabilities a member shall be allowed to earn additional income without reduction of the annuity herein provided for nonservice connected disabilities in an amount sufficient to make the total of the members extra earnings together with his annuity equal his final average monthly rate of pay computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately prior to the date on which annuity begins to accrue the annuity shall be reduced by fifty percent 50% of the amount the members extra earnings exceed his final average monthly rate of pay computed as aforesaid the foregoing limitations on earning additional income shall cease when the member becomes eligible to retire by reason of age and years of service administration of disability annuities a the determination of disability from any cause shall be made upon the basis of reports of examinations made by at least two 2 physicians designated by the board b a member receiving service connected or nonservice connected disability annuity shall be required to submit to an examination at least once each year by a physician or physicians designated by the board to determine whether the member is incapacitated for active service as a policeman or fireman and is entitled to receive a disability annuity the board may terminate a disability annuity upon evidence that the member is no longer disabled for service or if the member fails or refuses to submit to such examination for ten 10 days after he is notified to submit to such examination if upon such termination the member does not reenter service he shall be entitled to a refund of the excess if any of his contributions to the pension fund created herein without interest over the amount received by the member as a disability annuity c if a medical examination or an investigation made by the board discloses that the member is engaged or is able to engage in any gainful occupation resulting in earnings for services rendered in any capacity the disability annuity shall be reduced to an amount which when added to the members income from such gainful occupation does not exceed the current monthly salary being paid for the position or rank similar to that held by the member at the commencement of his disability if the examination or investigation aforesaid discloses that the member is able to engage in any gainful occupation and the member fails or refuses so to do then and in that event the disability annuity shall be terminated d any member receiving a disability annuity under the provisions of this submit to the board at least once each year in a form to be determined by the board a full complete and accurate statement of income for the preceding 12 months such statement of income may be used as a basis for adjusting any annuity payments made to a member under the provisions of this the member fails or refuses to furnish the board such statement of income within 10 days after the board requests the same or if the board determines that some material information contained in such statement of income is false the disability annuity shall be terminated e any disability annuity terminated because of the members failure or refusal to submit to an examination or reexamination by a physician or because of the members failure or refusal to engage in a gainful occupation when it is disclosed by a medical examination or investigation by the board that the member is able to do so or because of the members failure or refusal to submit a full complete and accurate statement of income shall be reinstated by the board at such time as it determines that the member is in compliance with the provisions of this which the annuity was terminated if the member fails for one year to comply with the aforesaid provisions the terminated disability shall not be reinstated and the same shall be revoked by the board service connected death a upon the death of a member resulting directly from service connected causes or from an occupational disease a surviving widow shall be entitled to an annuity equal to fifty percent 50% of the final average monthly salary of the decedent computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately preceding the death or the amount the decedent would have received monthly under section 11 of this he be deemed to have retired at the time of his death whichever amount is greater b in the event the decedent leaves no surviving widow or in the event a surviving widow remarries or dies then and in any of such events any surviving child or children of the deceased member under the age of 18 years shall receive fifty percent 50% of the decedents final average monthly salary computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately preceding the death until said child or the youngest of said children reaches the age of 18 years or marries whichever occurs first in the event there is more than one surviving child eligible for benefits under the provisions of this b then and in that event the total benefits due hereunder shall be divided equally among the eligible children nonservice connected death a upon the death of a member resulting from nonservice connected causes if the member had at least five 5 years of credited service a surviving widow shall be entitled to an annuity equal to the amount the deceased member would have received monthly under of this he be deemed to have retired at the time of his death b in the event the decedent leaves no surviving widow or in the event a surviving widow remarries or dies then and in any of such events any surviving child or children of the deceased member under the age of 18 years shall receive the amount fixed by a of this said child or the youngest of said children reaches the age of 18 years or marries whichever occurs first in the event there is more than one surviving child eligible for benefits under the provisions of this b then and in that event the total benefits due hereunder shall be divided equally among the eligible children c if under the provisions of this the beneficiaries named in this are determined not to be entitled to any benefits such beneficiaries shall be entitled to fifty percent 50% of all moneys contributed by the deceased member to the policemens or firemens pension fund of the city prior to the effective date of this one hundred percent 100% of all moneys contributed by the deceased member to the pension fund herein created subsequent to the effective date of this  service annuity retirement a any member having credited service of 22 years or more and having reached the age of 50 years may make application to be retired and if such application is made the board shall retire such member and pay him monthly payments in an amount equal to 228% of his final average monthly salary computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately prior to retirement multiplied by the number of years of credited service plus 11% of said final average monthly salary for each year of credited service in excess of 22 years provided however that in no event shall the service annuity paid hereunder exceed 66% of the members final average monthly salary b if any member be discharged or terminated by resignation of for any other reason after having credited service of 22 years the board shall order and direct that said member upon attaining the age of 50 years be paid monthly payments computed as provided in a above and subject to the 66% limitation contained therein except that the members final average monthly salary shall be computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately prior to his discharge or termination by resignation or other reason payment to widow after death of retired member if any member should die after having retired for age and service or for service only or for service connected disability leaving a widow said widow so long as she remains such widow shall receive monthly an amount equal to fifty percent 50% of the decedents average monthly compensation computed on the basis of the 12 months immediately preceding his retirement accounting and actuarial studies a the assets of the system shall be held for the express purposes set forth in the provisions of this to the conditions prescribed herein an adequate system of accounts and records shall be established and maintained to give effect to the requirements hereof and all assets of the system shall be credited to accounts according to the purposes for which they are held b an actuarial survey of the system shall be made at such times as the board deems proper and appropriate to check the mortality turnover disability interest and other actuarial factors assumed in calculations of liabilities and costs an annual actuarial valuation of the system shall be made at the close of each fiscal year for the purpose of establishing its financial condition and checking its current operating experience management  policy direction a the system created by this be construed to be a trust separate and distinct from all other entities the responsibility for the direction and operation of the system and for making effective the provisions hereof are hereby vested in a board of trustees which board shall be directly responsible to the governing body of the city the board shall consist of eight members as follows 1 the city manager  2 the chief of the police department and the chief of the fire department  3 the city attorney  4 two policemen and two firemen each having at least three years of credited service who shall be members of the system and shall be elected by the active members from the respective occupational groups as hereinafter provided according to the rules of election to be adopted by the board until elections for trustees are held the governing body of the city shall appoint four temporary trustees meeting the foregoing qualifications from among the policemen and firemen who shall hold office until permanent trustees are elected but the terms of such temporary trustees shall not extend for more than six month b the original elected trustees shall serve for the following terms one representing policemen for a term of two years and one for a term of four years  and one representing firemen for a term of two years and one for a term of four years the trustees so elected shall take office upon their election and shall succeed the temporary trustees appointed by the governing body of the city their terms of office shall expire on the third monday in april of the second and fourth year following their election as the case may be the trustees elected to succeed the original elected trustees shall serve for terms of four years c a permanent trustee shall continue in office until his successor is elected or appointed and has qualified any trustee who is a policeman or fireman shall be disqualified to serve in that capacity upon termination of service with the city if a vacancy occurs in the office of elective trustee a successor shall be elected for the unexpired term of office within 30 days by a special election unless the regular biannual election occurs sooner if a vacancy occurs in the office of an appointive trustee such vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the office was previously filled d each trustee shall take an oath that so far as it devolves upon him he will diligently and honestly administer the affairs of the board and that he will not knowingly or willfully permit to be violated any of the provisions of the ordinance applicable to the system such oath shall be subscribed by the person taking it and certified by the officer before whom it is taken and immediately filed with the city clerk a trustee shall be deemed to have qualified for membership on the board when such oath shall have been filed e subject to the limitations prescribed herein the board shall from time to time establish rules and regulations for the administration of the system and to implement the provisions of this ordinance as may be required it shall hold regular meetings at least quarterly in each year and such special meetings as may be deemed necessary provided however that written notice of such special meetings shall be given all trustees at least 48 hours in advance of the time fixed for such special meeting the annual meeting shall be held on the third wednesday of january of each year all meetings shall be open to the public a record of proceedings of all meetings shall be kept by the board and a copy thereof filed with the city clerk f each trustee shall be entitled to one vote on the board and the concurrence of five trustees shall be necessary for a decision at any regular or special meeting a trustee shall receive no salary as such while serving in that capacity officers and their duties the board shall have the following officers whose duties shall be prescribed by bylaws to be adopted by the board a a chairman and a vice chairman shall be elected from among its members b the administrator of the system shall be the city clerk who shall be an ex officio member of the board c the city treasurer ex officio shall be treasurer of the system and shall have custody of its moneys and securities all disbursements by the system shall be made by the treasurer upon authorization of the board d the city attorney shall be legal counsel to the board and shall represent the board in all legal matters affecting the system e an actuary may be appointed by the board to serve as technical advisor in the administration of the system on matters pertaining to the technical and actuarial aspects thereof f a physician or physicians shall be appointed at the discretion of the board to pass upon claims for service connected and nonservice connected disability annuities and service connected death annuities on medical questions pertaining to such claims and any other matter requiring medical advice that may arise in administration administration subject to the orders and resolutions of the board the administrator of the system shall a employ such clerical and professional services as may be required for the proper operation of the system whose compensation shall be fixed by the governing body of the city  b establish and maintain records files and accounts in such form and scope as will give full effect to the requirements of the system in accordance with the provisions hereof  c accumulate actuarial data concerning the operating experience of the system in such form as is necessary for the annual actuarial valuations and periodic actuarial studies in accordance with the recommendations of the actuary  d prepare periodic reports as may be required for the administration of the system  e prepare each year the annual report of the board to be submitted to the governing body of the city embodying among other things an accountants balance sheet supported by a statement of income and expenditures a listing of investments owned by the system a detailed statement of investments acquired and disposed of during the year covered by the report and such other financial and statistical data as may be deemed necessary for a proper interpretation of the condition of the system and the results of its operations the board shall cause to be distributed among the members of the system a synopsis of such annual report investments a the board may keep as an available fund for current disbursements by the system an amount not to exceed the requirements for such purposes for a period of ninety days any amounts in excess of the aforesaid current balance shall be invested in investments authorized for idle funds of the city by other ordinances of said city b the board shall have the power to hold purchase sell assign transfer and dispose of any of the securities in which moneys of the system have been invested as well as proceeds from such investments and any other property belonging to the system c all investments shall be clearly marked to indicate ownership of the system and to the extent possible shall be registered in its name no securities shall be purchased or sold or in any manner hypothecated except by action of the board duly entered in the record of its proceedings d any limitations affecting the purchase of securities shall be applicable only at the time of purchase and shall not require the liquidation of an investment at any time e no member or employee of the board shall have any direct interest in the income or gains from any investment made by the board nor shall any such person receive any pay or emolument for services in connection with any investment no member or employee of the board shall become an endorser or surety or in any manner an obligor for money loaned or borrowed from the system the governing body of the city may remove from office any member or employee of the board who violates the provisions of this e if threefourths of the members elect of such governing body vote in favor of such removal exemptions the right to a service retirement annuity disability annuity death annuity or any annuity or benefit under the provisions of this by whatever name called or a refund is personal with the recipient thereof and the assignment or transfer of any such annuity or benefit or any part thereof shall be void except as may be provided herein any such annuity or benefit shall not answer for debts contracted by the person receiving the same and it is the intention of this such annuity or benefits shall not be subject to execution attachment garnishment or affected by any judicial proceedings including bankruptcy monthly payments any service retirement annuity disability annuity death annuity or any other annuity provided herein shall be payable in equal monthly installments as a life annuity except as herein otherwise provided the first payment of any such annuity shall be made for the fraction of the month elapsing until the end of the first month  and in the case of the death of a retiree leaving no spouse or minor children the last payment shall be a partial annuity to be paid from the end of the month for which the last payment was made to and including the date of death and such payment shall be made to a relative fraud any person who knowingly makes any false statement or falsifies or permits to be falsified any record or records of this system in any attempt to defraud the system shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor the system and the city shall have the right to recover by setoff or otherwise any payments made under false representation if any such person be a member of the system or the beneficiary of a member heshe shall forfeit all rights to further participation in any of the benefits hereunder creation and maintenance of fund a for the purpose of funding the system and financing and paying the cost of the annuities and charter ordinance no 14  a charter ordinance exempting the city of wellington kansas from the provision of ksa 121696 to 1216101 inclusive and amendments thereto and providing substitute and additional provisions of the same subject relating to the levy of a transient guest tax for tourism and conventions be it ordained by the governing body of the city of wellington kansas the city of wellington kansas by virtue of the power vested in it by of the constitution of the state of kansas hereby elects to and does exempt itself from and make inapplicable to it ksa 121696 to 1216101 inclusive and all amendments thereto which apply to this city but which do not apply uniformly to all cities and provide substitute and additional provisions on the same subject as hereinafter provided as used in this ordinance the following words and phrases shall be defined as follows a person is any individual firm partnership corporation joint venture or other association of persons  b hotel or motel is any structure or building which contains rooms furnished for the purposes of providing lodging which may or may not also provide meals entertainment or various other personal services to transient guests and which is kept used maintained advertised or held out to the public as a place where sleeping accommodations are sought for pay or compensation by transient or permanent guests  c transient guests is a person who occupies a room in a hotel or motel for not more that 28 consecutive days  d hotel or motel business is any person engaged in the business of renting leasing or letting quarters sleeping accommodations rooms or a part thereof in connection with any hotel or motel  e tourism is the practice of touring or traveling for recreation business or education  f touring is a trip excursion or circular journey for business recreation or education the governing body of said city is hereby authorized to levy a transient guest tax at not to exceed the rate of two percent 2% upon the gross receipts derived from or paid by transient guests for sleeping accommodations exclusive of charges for incidental services or facilities in any hotel or motel the percentage and effective date shall be specified in a resolution authorizing the same such tax so levied shall be based upon gross rental receipts collected by any hotel or motel business the tax levied pursuant to this ordinance shall be paid by the transient guest to the hotel or motel business and it shall be the duty of each and every such business to collect from the transient guest the full amount of any such tax or an amount equal as nearly as possible or practicable to the average equivalent thereto each hotel or motel business collecting the tax levied under this be responsible for paying the same over to the state department of revenue shall administer and enforce the collection of such tax as provided in ksa 1985 supp 121698 and 121698a there is hereby created and established on the books of the city a fund to be known as the tourism and convention fund to be used for the purpose of a contracting with any agency organization or group of firms to promote conventions and tourism within the city and its environs and b providing for the expenditures in connection with promotion of convention and tourism the tax levied and collected under this become due and payable in the manner prescribed by ksa 1985 supp 121698 and amendments thereto all such taxes after the two percent 2% deduction to defray the expenses of the department of revenue in the administration and enforcement thereof shall be remitted by the department to the city and shall be credited to the tourism and convention fund hereinabove created there is hereby established a committee to be known as the convention and tourism committee which shall make recommendations to the governing body of the city concerning the programs and expenditures from the tourism and convention fund for promotion of conventions and tourism said committee shall consist of seven 7 members to be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council the first committee shall consist of four 4 members whose terms shall expire on  and three members whose terms shall expire on  thereafter successor members of such committee shall be appointed for terms of two years each such member to serve until a successor is appointed and qualified vacancies on said committee shall be filled by appointment of the mayor with the approval of the council for the unexpired term of the vacancy filled four 4 members of the committee shall be appointed as representatives of owners operators or employees of persons engaged in the hotel or motel business within the city regardless of whether the appointee resides within or without the corporate limits of the city three 3 members of the committee shall be appointed as representatives of the following groups  a representatives from agencies or organizations actively engaged in promoting tourism or from facilities or organizations of historic or cultural attractions in the city or its environs  b members of the general public  c employees of the city or members of city boards or commissions the mayor shall designate which of the foregoing groups each appointee represents and no more than four 4 representatives from any one of said groups shall be members of the committee at the same time no compensation in any form whatsoever shall be paid or given any members of the committee for service thereon any member of the committee who is absent from three consecutive regular meetings of the committee shall be deemed to have resigned and the vacancy created thereby shall be filed as hereinabove provided the convention and tourism committee shall elect a chairman and a secretary who shall also serve as vicechairman of such committee and shall hold regular meetings at a time and place to be determined by the committee subject to the approval of the governing body of the city all meetings of such committee shall be held and conducted in conformity with the provisions of the kansas open meetings law the convention and tourism committee shall annually consider all requests received by it for expenditure of moneys from the tourism and convention fund of the city and shall prepare a budget and make recommendations for such expenditures to the governing body of the city prior to july 1 of each year the governing body of the city after considering the recommendations of the committee shall adopt a budget for such fund that may or may not conform to the budget and recommendations of the committee upon the adoption of a resolution provided for in of this the governing body of the city shall have the authority to contract for the expenditure of moneys from tourism and convention fund of the city subject however to the provisions of the kansas cash basis law and the kansas budget law this charter ordinance shall be published once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper this charter ordinance shall take effect 61 days after final publication unless a sufficient petition for a referendum is filed and a referendum held on the ordinance provided in c3 of the constitution of kansas in which case the ordinance shall become effective if approved by the majority of the electors voting thereon passed by the governing body not less than twothirds of the memberselect voting in favor thereof the 2nd day of september 1986 charter ordinance no 15  a charter ordinance exempting the of wellington kansas a city organized under the laws of the state of kansas as a city of the second class by virtue of its home rule power vested in it by  of the constitution of the state of kansas the general election to be held in the year 201 the city shall be divided into three 3 districts as equal in population as practical based on the latest decennial census available from the us census bureau that the boundaries of said three 3 districts will be defined by an ordinary ordinance at a later time that the citys four 4 wards and eight 8 precincts are abolished after the year 2012 c that for the four 4 council positions up for election in the year 201 members shall be elected to serve a one 1 year term commencing the second council meeting in april of 2012 d that for the six 6 council members up for election in the year 201 the top votegetter from each district shall serve a four 4 year term commencing the second council meeting in april of 201 and the succeeding election four 4 years thereafter that the second top votegetter from each district shall serve a term of two 2 years commencing the second council meeting in april of 201 then be up for election in the year 2015 to serve a four 4 year term commencing the second council meeting in april of 201 and the succeeding election four 4 years thereafter if a tie vote should occur then a determination of who was elected will be done in accordance with the applicable state statute e that after the year 201 each voter in each district shall have one vote for each city council seat in their district that is up for election that after the year 201 primary elections are eliminated f that after the year 201 the position of mayor shall be elected by the city at large to serve a four 4 year term commencing the second council meeting in april of 201 and the succeeding election four 4 years thereafter g that each voter shall have one 1 vote for the position of mayor that is up for election h that after the year 201 term limits shall take effect limiting a citizen from being elected to serve two 2 consecutive terms as either mayor or as a council member charter adopted  charter adopted  and charter staffing and managing of programs  b business means any person engaged in the business of renting leasing or letting living quarters sleeping accommodations rooms or a part thereof in connection with any motel hotel or tourist court  c economic development promotion means 1 activities to attract the location or relocation of industrial or commercial enterprises into the community efforts including d hotel motel or tourist court means any structure or building which contains rooms furnished for the purposes of providing lodging which may or may not also provide meals entertainment or various other personal services to transient guests and which is kept used maintained advertised or held out to the public as a place where sleeping accommodations are sought for pay or compensation by transient or permanent guests and having more than two bedrooms furnished for the accommodation of such guests  e person means an individual firm partnership corporation joint venture or other association of persons  f transient guest means a person who occupies a room in a hotel motel or tourist court for not more than 28 consecutive days  the city by the power vested in it by of the facilities in any hotel motel or tourist court the percentage of such tax shall be determined by said governing body and shall be specified in a resolution authorizing the same the city by the power ksa 14301 et seq president of the council the city council shall elect one of its own body as president of the council and the president of the council shall preside at all meetings of the council in the absence of the mayor in the absence of the mayor and president of the council the council shall elect one of its own body as acting president of the council the president and acting president when occupying the place of the mayor shall have the same privileges as other councilmembers they shall preside as mayor but may debate and otherwise act as councilmembers and all acts of the president or acting president while so acting are as binding upon the city as if done by the mayor    state law reference president of the council ksa 14204 vacancy in office of mayor or councilmember a when any vacancy shall happen in the office of mayor by death resignation removal from the city removal from office refusal to qualify or otherwise the president of the council for the time being shall exercise the office of mayor with all the rights privileges and jurisdiction of the mayor until such vacancy be filled or such disability be removed or in case of temporary absence until the mayor shall return during the time the president of the council shall so act the president of the council shall receive the same compensation that the mayor would be entitled in case of such vacancy other than a temporary absence or disability the person exercising the office of mayor shall become mayor thereupon the council shall elect from its membership a new president of the council b whenever a vacancy shall occur in the office of a councilmember the governing body shall appoint an elector from the cityatlarge to be a councilmember for the balance of the unexpired term     ii 12172013 state performance of the city managers duties in the amount of $4000000    duties the city manager shall 1 be responsible for all administrative affairs of the city and see that the laws of the state and ordinances of the city are enforced  2 appoint and remove all heads of departments and subordinate officers and employees of the city all such appointments shall be made upon merit and fitness alone  3 be responsible for the discipline of all appointive officers and may without notice cause the affairs of any department or the conduct of any officer or employee to be examined or terminated  4 set salaries guided by the wage scale set by the governing body and within the limitations of the budget adopted by the governing body of the city  5 prepare and submit the annual budget to the governing body and also keep the governing body fully advised as to the financial condition and needs of the city  6 make recommendations to the governing body on all matters concerning the welfare of the city and shall have a seat but no vote in all of the public meetings of the governing body the city manager shall give a written or oral monthly report to the governing body regarding city affairs  7 perform such other and further duties as may be required by law or ordinance    state law reference duties of the city manager ksa 121024 powers a the city manager may perform the duties of any law reference cereal malt beverages ksa 412701 definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning cereal malt beverage as used in this act includes enhanced cereal malt beverage and is defined as cereal malt beverage and enhanced cereal malt beverage as those terms are defined in ksa 412701 and amendments thereto as defined by and such terms in this article shall include beer containing not more than six percent alcohol by volume when such beer is sold by a retailer licensed under the kansas cereal malt beverage act general retailer means a person who has a license to sell cereal malt beverages at retail for consumption on the licensed premises limited retailer means a person who has a license to sell cereal malt beverages at retail only in original and unopened containers and not for consumption on the premises place of business means any place at which cereal malt beverages or alcoholic beverages or both are sold retailer means any person who sells or offers for sale any cereal malt beverage for use or consumption and not for resale in any form wholesaler or distributor  any individuals firms copartnerships corporations and associations which sell or offer for sale any beverage referred to in this chapter to persons copartnerships corporations and associations authorized by this chapter to sell cereal malt beverages at retail     i 3192019 state law reference definitions ksa 41102 412701 license required of retailers a it shall be unlawful for any person to sell any cereal malt beverage at retail without a license for each place of business where cereal malt beverages are to be sold at retail b it shall be unlawful for any person having a license to sell cereal malt beverages at retail only in the original and unopened containers and not for consumption on the premises to sell any cereal malt beverage in any other manner    state law reference retailers license ksa 412702 license application a any person desiring a license to sell cereal malt beverages in the city shall make an application to the governing body which shall be accompanied by the required license fee for each place of business for which the person desires a license the application shall be verified and upon a form prepared by the attorney general of the state and shall contain 1 the name and residence of the applicant and how long the applicant has resided in the state  2 the particular place for which the license is desired  3 the name of the owner of the premises upon which the place of business is located  4 the names and addresses of all persons who have any financial interest in the particular place of business for which the license is desired  5 a statement that the applicant is a citizen of the united states of america and not less than 21 years of age and that the applicant has not within two years immediately preceding the date of making the application been convicted of a felony or any crime involving moral turpitude or been adjudged guilty of drunkenness or driving a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or the violation of any other intoxicating liquor law of any state or of the united states of america b each application for a retailers license must be accompanied by a certificate from the city fire chief certifying that the fire chief has inspected the premises to be licensed and that the same comply with the fire code andor ordinances of the city all applications for a license shall be accompanied by a statement signed by the applicant authorizing any governmental agency to provide the city with any information pertinent to the application one copy of such application shall immediately be transmitted to the chief of police for investigation of the applicant it shall be the duty of the chief of police to investigate such applicant to determine whether the applicant is qualified as a licensee under the provisions of this article the chief of police shall report to the city clerk not later than five working days after the receipt of such application the application shall be scheduled for consideration by the governing body at the earliest meeting consistent with the procedures set forth in this article    state law reference license application ksa 412702 procedures a all applications for a new or renewed cereal malt beverage license shall be submitted to the city clerk at least 15 days in advance of the governing body meeting at which they will be considered b the city clerk shall notify the holder of an existing license 30 days in advance of its expiration c the city clerk shall furnish copies of all applications to the police department and to the fire department when they are received the police department shall run a records check on all applicants and other persons whose character or history may affect the issuance of a license the fire department shall inspect the premises to ascertain compliance with the fire codes andor ordinances of the city the departments will then recommend approval or disapproval of applications within five working days of the departments receipt of the application d the governing body will not consider any application for a new or renewed license that has not been submitted 15 days in advance and reviewed by the police and fire departments of the city e an applicant who does not already hold a cereal malt beverage license in the city shall be required to attend the governing body meeting when the application for a new license is to be considered    restriction on location no license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any cereal malt beverage on premises which are located in areas not zoned for such purpose    3 state law reference authority to restrict location ksa 412704a license disqualification no license shall be issued to 1
